Award.AwardTitle: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Building a Friction-free High-speed Science Network and DMZ to Support Data-intensive Research and Education at The College of New Jersey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes a program of high-speed network upgrades at The College of New Jersey (TCNJ) to support cutting-edge computational research and education. Insufficient access to TCNJ's High Performance Computing cluster previously created a bottleneck that limited scientific research and training. These enhancements to TCNJ's science network will expand research capacity and efficiency, particularly in computationally intensive fields, including biochemistry, astrophysics, phylogenomics, high-resolution microscopy, and undergraduate science education, and will provide students with greater access to research opportunities in laboratories and classrooms while contributing to the preparation of a computationally literate workforce. The upgrades enable faster data acquisition and propagation and enhancing the research and external collaborations of the College's many computationally intensive researchers, including both faculty members and undergraduate students. Finally, as part of this project, a new data visualization short course is exposing a greater number of undergraduate students to TCNJ's computing resources.

This project implements a new high-speed science network and DMZ at The College of New Jersey (TCNJ) to support cutting-edge computational research and education where insufficient access to TCN's High Performance Computing cluster previously created a bottleneck that limited scientific research and training. This project directly connects TCNJ's science buildings to its High Performance Computing cluster via a new 80 Gigabit per second (Gbps) backbone and 10 Gbps connections to targeted labs, classrooms, and offices. A new Science DMZ that uses the SciPass OpenFlow application is also being implemented. SciPass supports friction-free interconnectivity by automatically allowing "good" data flows to bypass the Science Network firewall in real-time. Network performance is being assessed and nationally benchmarked using perfSONAR, and a new collaboration with Open Science Grid is allowing TCNJ to connect directly to this distributed computing federation's national infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science faculty at The College of New Jersey (TCNJ) are conducting novel, groundbreaking research requiring large amounts of data and advanced computational resources. A major obstacle faced by TCNJ faculty is moving scientific data in and out of the College?s High Performance Computing (HPC)  cluster in a timely manner. This NSF Campus CyberInfrastructure award allowed TCNJ to install a new Science Network featuring a high-speed dedicated backbone independent of the general campus network. The new Science Network has connectivity for access to the Internet, Internet2 and other campus computing resources and consists of a backbone of dual 40-gigabit links in a port-share configuration, effectively providing 80Gbps of bandwidth. Labs, offices and classrooms that generate large amounts of scientific data and are located throughout the School of Science?s Biology, Chemistry, Physics/Math and STEM buildings have special, high-speed connections to the backbone. Not only does the Science Network provide more bandwidth than the general campus network, it also prevents TCNJ?s scientists from having to compete with general campus network traffic when transferring their data. The Science Network includes a Science DMZ with a Data Transfer Node (DTN) and utilizes the SciPass/OpenFlow network architecture. This allows identified ?good? data flows to bypass the limited throughput firewall to gain access to the full network bandwidth during the life of the flow.

 

Intellectual Merit: The Science Network has enabled TCNJ faculty and student researchers the ability to quickly and efficiently transfer large amounts of data between their workstation and the TCNJ HPC resource for the purpose of computation and visualization. TCNJ?s scientific instruments, such as microscopes and telescopes, can generate large amounts of data. Previously, faculty had to decide on what to delete from these devices to free up storage space or employ a cumbersome archive procedure. The new Science Network allows them to simply drag-and-drop files to cluster storage for immediate archiving and future retrieval. This has improved research outcomes and allowed TCNJ faculty and undergraduate students to advance their work in a wide diversity of disciplines, including computational biochemistry, computational astrophysics, phylogenomics and macroevolution, and disciplines using high-resolution microscopy. 

 

Broader Impacts: The Science Network has enabled access to HPC cluster resources directly from the classroom. Faculty can easily demonstrate topics that require the HPC resources during a course lecture. In addition, because students use simple tools like a web browser or terminal emulator to access HPC cluster resources over the Science Network, it helps democratize access to powerful HPC software and hardware while freeing faculty from the burden of worrying if an assignment will run on every student?s computer. Finally, as faculty incorporate HPC cluster resources such as Jupyter Labs and visualization tools into their course curriculum and undergraduate research, they expose more students to these technologies which prepares them for their use in graduate school or the workforce.

The network  also allows for specific use cases in undergraduate laboratory classes. One case includes uploading and downloading large phylogenetic datasets which can take several hours to do over the existing campus network connections. Using the new Science Network speeds up these transfers by 10 to 100 times, allowing students to collect, evaluate and visualize their data during a single class. There are other similar cases involving computational physics and computational chemistry datasets. In addition, the Science Network allows faculty to remotely control scientific instruments, such as the scanning electron microscope (SEM), from the classroom, efficiently and safely demonstrating these advanced pieces of instrumentation to large groups of undergraduate students.

Finally, In addition to expanding local access to the HPC cluster, the Science Network has allowed TCNJ to partner with the Open Science Grid (OSG). Idle CPU and GPU compute resources are shared with OSG member researchers through the OSG managed service. TCNJ also participates in the OSG perfSONAR mesh for network performance monitoring and performance reporting. An agreement is in place to share HPC training materials between TCNJ and the OSG.
